intro: Jatropha texana, commonly known as the Texas spurge, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Euphorbiaceae family, characterized by its milky sap and showy, yellowish-green flowers. The plant typically grows as a low shrub or perennial herb, often found in dry, rocky soils. Its leaves are alternate, ovate, and have a rough texture, while its fruits are capsule-like and contain toxic seeds. Jatropha texana is adapted to arid environments and plays a role in local ecosystems by providing habitat and food for certain wildlife.
